subject: HIGH PRIEST AND LAMB
verse: Christ sacrificed for their sins once for  all when He offered Himself. (Hebrews 7:27)
reflection:
The Good Friday event, the death of Christ, is viewed in Holy Writ from two points of view. It presents Christ in the dual role of the sacrificing priest and of the offering that He brought.The Hebrews epistle emphasis to Christ as our High Priest. Other Scripture add to that by speaking of Christ as the sacrificial Lamb. John the Baptist
called Jesus the Lamb of God, and St. Paul,
writing to the Corinthians, declared, “Christ, our Passover Lamb, has been sacrificed [for us]” (I Corinthians 5:7)
prayer: Tell the Savor that you are sorry that your sins caused His death, but thankful that it brought you life.

subject: BEING A SERVANT
verse: For even I, the Son of Man did not come  to be served, but to serve, and to give My  life as a ransom for many. (Mark 10:45)
reflection:
Jesus was the greatest servant who ever lived. When we think of our relationship to Christ, can it be said of us that we want only to serve Him?
As a well- known missionary retuned to the U. S., a reporter asked, “ have you found happiness in Africa?” The missionary answered, “I have found a place of service, and that is enough

prayer: [Let us make this our prayer] “O God, help me to be the master of myself, that I may be a servant of others.”

reflection: The message Mary delivered explains why Jesus said she shouldn’t touch Him: “I have not yet returned to my Father.” He was tell- ing her that a relation much closer than bod- ily contact is coming. prayer: Express your gratitude to the risen Christ for His love that took Him to the cross for your salvation.

subject: WORSHIP WITH BELLS ON
verse: The gold bells and the pomegranates are  to alternate around the hem of the robe.  (Exodus 28:34)
reflection:
The verse above gives insight into a difference between the Old and New Testaments. God’s ceremonial law prescribed ever so many things, not only pertaining to the Sabbath and to circumcision, but down to the details of the High Priest’s robe. As New
Testament people, we are accustomed to exercising freedom as to the design and use of a pastor’s vestments, the order of worship in church services, and the like. We have freedom in such things because God has neither comman- ded nor forbidden them in the New Test- ament. But any freedom is always to be used responsibly .
prayer: Give thanks to God who, for Jesus’ sake, has freed us from bon dage to the Law, asking Him that we may never mislead others by our freedoms.

Dear to the God are those who are ever- green, and ever bearing. He blesses them and makes them a blessing to many. The
Lord cautions us regarding people who seem like dead trees, without foliage or fruit. He does not want us to cut them from the member-ship of the church. He tells us to remember that He will with the sunshine of grace, nurture them and cause them to grow in faith and bear spiritual fruit again. Through our Baptism, God has grafted us to Him. He causes our faith to live and make us “trees of righteousness.” He sent His Son, Jesus Christ to die on a tr ee and to earn our righteousness.
prayer: It is in Christ that we find the life we need.

subject: THE "IF" IS REMOVED:
verse: If only for this life we have hope in Christ,  we are to be pitied more than all men.  (I Corinthians 15:19)
reflection:
Why does Paul say believers are to be pitied “IF” there were only earthly value to Christianity? Well in Paul’s day, Christianity often brought a person
persecution, and ostracism from family, and, in many cases, poverty. There were few tangible benefits from becominging a Christian in that society. It was certainly not a step up the social or career ladder.
More important is the fact that “IF” Christ had not been resurrected from the dead, Christians would not be forgiven of their sins or have any hope of eternal life.
prayer: Express your thankfulness to God for validating your faith by raising Jesus from the dead.

subject: THE HEAVENLY FATHER PROVIDES
verse: “Consider the ravens, they do not sow or reap,  they have no storeroom or barn, yet God feeds them.” (Luke 12:24)
reflection: Jesus points out that the birds are not only providers for others but that God provides for them. The lesson is: God’s people are not to worry about the future. They are, to be sure: to make plans but they are not to doubt the faithfulness of their provider. God, our Creator and Provider, is also our Redeemer. God’s Son came to earth to quench the hunger and thirst of the soul by making full restitution for our sins. Through Him we are redeemed from sin and death.
prayer: Thank God for providing food for your body and spiritual sustenance through the Gospel of Christ.

subject: THE KINGDOM OF LITTLE CHILDREN

reflection:
Jesus cautions us to avoid setting a bad example or causing children to sin. He wants us to teach them what is good and true by both Word and example. Sooner or later they will have to come to grips with the evil around them.
Christ is pleased when we teach children – and when
we learn from them—for of such is God’s King- dom.
prayer: Ask God to give you sincere faith and never doubt Jesus’ love.
